# Physiology


## Hydrops

A change in the structure of the membranous labyrinth @walterIdentificationManagementUnilateral.

Hydrops refers to labyrinth distension @walterIdentificationManagementUnilateral.

Generally occurs in the otolithic organs (utricle and saccule) rather than the SCCs @walterIdentificationManagementUnilateral.

# Signs

- Yaw plane signs
    - horizontal nystagmus @herdmanVestibularRehabilitation2014
    - past pointing @herdmanVestibularRehabilitation2014
    - rotational and lateral body falls @herdmanVestibularRehabilitation2014
    - Horizontal deviation of perceived straight-ahead @herdmanVestibularRehabilitation2014
- Roll plane signs
    - torsional nystagmus @herdmanVestibularRehabilitation2014
    - skew deviation @herdmanVestibularRehabilitation2014
    - ocular torsion @herdmanVestibularRehabilitation2014
    - tilts of head, body, and perceived vertical @herdmanVestibularRehabilitation2014
- Pitch plane signs
    - upbeat/downbeat nystagmus @herdmanVestibularRehabilitation2014
    - forward/backward tilts and falls @herdmanVestibularRehabilitation2014
    - vertical deviations of perceived straight-ahead. @herdmanVestibularRehabilitation2014


# Nystagmus

Nystagmus is one of the primary diagnostic indicators for both peripheral and central vestibular pathologies @fulkOSullivanSchmitzsPhysical2024.


Nystagmus consists of 2 components: a slow drifting eye movement followed by a fast eye movement in the opposite direction.


Nystagmus direction is described based on the direction of the **fast** component



|||
|-|-|
|Asymmetry in vestibular firing rate||
|VOR |Eyes slowly drift towards the side with *slower* firing|
|Parapontine reticular formation @fulkOSullivanSchmitzsPhysical2024 | Fast eye movement in opposite direction to reset gaze |

Nystagmus can be described using:

- Direction
- Spontaneity

# Unstable/Progressive Unilateral Vestibular Disorders

### Meniere's Disease

- Hydrops (Hydropic changes) almost always @walterIdentificationManagementUnilateral
- Increases risk with age @walterIdentificationManagementUnilateral
    - Almost never in children @walterIdentificationManagementUnilateral
    - Rarely in young adults @walterIdentificationManagementUnilateral
- Ethnicity
    - &darr; African Americans @walterIdentificationManagementUnilateral
    - &uarr; European descent @walterIdentificationManagementUnilateral
- Re-occurrence
    - 1/5 patients have meniere's disease on the opposite side later in life @walterIdentificationManagementUnilateral
- Otolithic Crisis Events of Tumarkin
- Increased risk of Secondary BPPV @walterIdentificationManagementUnilateral

#### Otolithic Crisis Events of Tumarkin

- Conscious drop attacks @walterIdentificationManagementUnilateral
- No warning @walterIdentificationManagementUnilateral
- Violent @walterIdentificationManagementUnilateral
- Brief @walterIdentificationManagementUnilateral
- Generally late stages of Meniere's disease @walterIdentificationManagementUnilateral
- No vertigo @walterIdentificationManagementUnilateral
- Feels as if you were pushed @walterIdentificationManagementUnilateral

### Vestibular Schwannoma (Acoustic Neuroma)

Growth which impinges the *CNVIII Vestibulocochlear n.* resulting 

- MRI
    - Internal Auditory Canal (IAC) MRI + Contrast is best @walterIdentificationManagementUnilateral
    - Normal cuts of the brain have poor visibility of [CNVIII]({{< var ref-cn8.path >}}) @walterIdentificationManagementUnilateral

Common Symptoms

- Unilateral and insidious Hearing loss @walterIdentificationManagementUnilateral
- Dizziness (1/5) @walterIdentificationManagementUnilateral
- Unilateral insidious Tinnitus @walterIdentificationManagementUnilateral 


Treatment

- Resection
    - Risk of *CNVII Facial n.* damage @walterIdentificationManagementUnilateral

### Semicircular Canal Dehiscence (SCD)

- Superior Canal Dehiscence (SSCD)
- 

absence in bone overlying the superior canal @walterIdentificationManagementUnilateral

CAT scans are helpful in identifying @walterIdentificationManagementUnilateral

::: {.callout-note}
This *can* occur in other canals, but most commonly occurs involving the superior canal @walterIdentificationManagementUnilateral.
:::

::: {.callout-caution}
Just because a patient *appears* to have SCD per imaging, does not mean we can diagnose them @walterIdentificationManagementUnilateral.

The conclusion from imaging can only be that a patient "does not have SCD" or "may have SCD" @walterIdentificationManagementUnilateral.
:::

- Pressure sensitivity
    - Sneezing
    - Coughing
    - Valsalva @walterIdentificationManagementUnilateral
    - Lifting @walterIdentificationManagementUnilateral
    - Bowel movements @walterIdentificationManagementUnilateral
- Imbalance
    - Worsened with head movement @walterIdentificationManagementUnilateral
    - Dark environments @walterIdentificationManagementUnilateral
- Sound Sensitivity
    - Internal: Sound coming from your own body
        - Heel strike @walterIdentificationManagementUnilateral
        - Eye movement @walterIdentificationManagementUnilateral
        - Heartbeat @walterIdentificationManagementUnilateral
        - Autophony @walterIdentificationManagementUnilateral
    - External (sound from the environment)


Tullio's phenomena: nystagmus induced by sound @walterIdentificationManagementUnilateral

::: {.callout-note}
There is increase internal sound hypersensitivity since the dehiscence causes amplification in the ear of vibrations within the body @walterIdentificationManagementUnilateral
:::

Testing:

- Pressure provocation nystagmus test
    - Put pressure into the ear using a pneumatic otoscope to increase (positive) and decrease (negative) pressure into the ear
    - Sometimes the pressure can move into the superior canal in SCD patients @walterIdentificationManagementUnilateral
    - The changes in pressure billow the cupula @walterIdentificationManagementUnilateral
    - This results in nystagmus @walterIdentificationManagementUnilateral

- Sound provoked nystagmus test

- Vent testing


Management

- Therapy has little improvements
- Surgical repair is effective

- Minor symptoms
    - Education
    - Education that they are not having psychiatric symptoms

# Peripheral vs Central

- Nystagmus
    - Does not change direction with gaze for peripheral @walterIdentificationManagementUnilateral
    - Changes direction with gaze for central disorders @walterIdentificationManagementUnilateral
